questions.text: The presence of strange sensations described by the patient as being imposed on the body by ‘some external agency’, with the patient being a passive recipient, is known as :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Somatic passivity phenomenon: Somatic passivity is the presence of strange sensations described by the patient as being imposed on the body by ‘some external agency’, with the patient being a passive recipient. It is one of the Schneider’s first rank symptoms.

questions.text: A person was asked about his family. He starts with the number of family members and who they are but moves onto the description of city he studies in, to the weather and then to the automobiles and so on, giving some details for each topic before moving on to next topic. This is an example of disorder of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Form

Derailment (loosening of associations): is slow and progressive digression from the original topic. The topics are not related to each other. However, the chunks of speech covering various topics are syntactically correct and are meaningful. For example, a person is asked about his family. He starts with the number of family members and who they are but moves onto the description of city he studies in, to the weather and then to the automobiles and so on, giving some details for each topic before moving on to next topic.

questions.text: "VORBEIREDEN" term is synonymous with all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Word salad

Ganser’s syndrome is hysterical pseudodementia, seen in prisoner’s , where they give approximate answers, known as talking past the point, also known as vorbeireiden

choices.text: Delusion of grandiosity, persecution and reference

questions.text: A patient believes he is the most important person in the world than anyone so his neighbours and family is trying to harm him as they are jealous of him. His wife says otherwise and says he behaves like this recently only before he was working as a school teacher peacefully and brought to OPD. He is suffering from? (AIIMS)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Delusion of grandiosity and persecution 

(Ref : Fish’s psychopathology)

Feeling that I am the most important person in the world is grandiosity and family is jealous of him, want to harm him is persecution. Its not uncommon for persecution and grandiosity to co-exist.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A : 2 , B : 3 , C : 4 , D : 1

Correct match should be

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl is able to perceive colors when she listens to cello music. This phenomenon is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Synesthesia

Synesthesia: It is mingling of senses. People with synesthesia may see a color when they hear something or hear a tone when they see a color.
Extracampine hallucinations: Hallucinations occur outside the normal field of perception. Eg: Images seen behind your back

Cenesthetic hallucination: Visceral and deep tissue perceptions that are inconsistent with internal sensory apparatus. Eg: burning sensation in brain
Functional hallucination: Stimulus in one modality produces hallucinations in the same modality. Eg: Voices heard simultaneously when ever the noise of water ruuning through a tap is heard.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Fish’s Symptoms of Psychiatry, 4th edition

questions.text: A person presents to psychiatry OPD with  pains at multiple sites, associated with weakness, low mood, decreased enjoyment, always worried about his illness, saying that all problem  he has is due to a “medical condition” which is not treated well yet, what is his level of INSIGHT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Grade III

Grades of insight:

Complete denial of illness 

Slight awareness of being sick and needing help but denying it at the same time 

Awareness of being sick but blaming it on others, on external factors, on medical or unknown organic factors 

Intellectual insight: Admission of illness and recognition that symptoms or failures in social adjustment are due to irrational feelings or disturbances, without applying that knowledge to future experiences 

True emotional insight: Emotional awareness of the motives and feelings within, of the underlying meaning of symptoms; does the awareness lead to changes in personality and future behavior; openness to new ideas and concepts about self and the important persons in his or her life

questions.text: As per recent ICD 11, for making diagnosis of “delusional disorder”, minimum duration of symptoms required is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

3 months

Delusional disorder is characterized by the development of a delusion or set of related delusions that persist for at least 3 months, which occur in the absence of a Depressive, Manic, or Mixed mood episode. Other characteristic symptoms of Schizophrenia (e.g. persistent auditory hallucinations, disorganized thinking, negative symptoms)are not present

questions.text: Which of the following suggests a psychotic rather than organic disorder?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text:
Which of the following is seen in schizophrenia
1. Delusions of persecution 

2. Delusions of reference 

3. Delusions of grandeur

4. Delusions of control 

5. Somatic delusions
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1,2,3,4,5

The commonly seen delusions in schizophrenia include: 

1. Delusions of persecution (being persecuted against, e.g. ‘people are against me’). 

2. Delusions of reference (being referred to by others; e.g. ‘people are talking about me’). 

3. Delusions of grandeur (exaggerated self-importance; e.g. ‘I am God almighty’). 

4. Delusions of control (being controlled by an external force, known or unknown; e.g. ‘My neighbour is controlling me”). 

5. Somatic (or hypochondriacal) delusions (e.g. ‘there are insects crawling in my scalp’).

questions.text:
There are four patients A, B, C and D. Each having a characteristic symptom- 

A- Excessive and irrational fantasy thinking

B- Significant inability to decide between two options or choices and unable to take a decision in most cases.

C- Emotional disturbances like inappropriate affect

D- Showing apparently meaningful behaviours at time for which he doesn’t have any memory later on

Who is least likely to have Schizophrenia ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

D
 
A, B and C are showing three out of the 4 A’s of Bleuer which are- Autism, Ambivalence and Affect disturbances. The symptom of D is called as “Automatism” which is associated with Epilepsy and not Schizophrenia.

choices.text: Belief that one has the power of an alien species

questions.text: A 54-year-old, psychotic, homeless man is brought into the emergency department by the police for medical clearance, after being picked up for aggressive behavior and disorderly conduct. He has a history of alcoholism, substance abuse, as well as poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension. Which of the following symptoms is most specific to a diagnosis of schizophrenia, as opposed to other etiologies of psychosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Although all these symptoms can be seen in various psychotic disorders, the presence of a bizarre delusion is the most specific to schizophrenia. Only one psychotic symptom is needed to diagnose schizophrenia if there are bizarre delusions, auditory hallucinations commenting on the patient, or two or more voices speaking to each other.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with schizophrenia, has decreased social interaction, lack of any drive/motivation and reduced emotional expressions. Which of the following marked pathway is most likely involved in causation of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mesocortical pathway

The symptoms described in the question are negative symptoms and negative symptoms are related to decreased dopamine in mesocortical pathway (from ventral tegmental area of midbrain to prefrontal cortex)

A: Nigrostriatal

B. Mesolimbic

C. Mesocortical

D. Tubero infundibular

questions.text: "Early onset schizophrenia" means onset of schizophrenic symptoms before the age of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Onset before 18 years

Remember. 

1. After 45 y of age to call as late onset schizophrenia

2. Before 18 y early onset

3. Before 13 y childhood onset

questions.text: All are good prognostic indicators of schizophrenia except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Slow and gradual onset

questions.text: Ramesh is a model patient on the ward. He is never in any trouble. Whatever he is told to do he does. He sits quietly for hours, rarely talking, and hardly moving, except to ape the movements of those who pass by him. The most likely diagnosis for Ramesh is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Catatonic schizophrenia can be of two types: agitated and stuporous. Ramesh is an example of the stuporous type. Residual phase means no or few apparent symptoms.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy was diagnosed to have Schizophrenia and was given injection fluphenazine 25 mg depot injection as he was not compliant to the treatment. He was brought to the ER in the night with uprolling of eyes, and head and neck twisted towards one side . What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The clinical picture described above is Acute Dystonia.

Acute Dystonia:

Signs and symptoms:

•  Muscular spasm in any part of the body. (E.g., oculogyric spasm, torticolis)

•  Inability to swallow and speak clearly

Prevalence: 10%

Risk factors:

•  Young males

•  High potency medications

•  In those who are antipsychotic naive

It occurs within hours of starting antipsychotic.

Treatment:

•  Intramuscular/ intravenous anticholinergic drug such as promethazine

Reference: Maudsley’s Prescribing guidelines, 14th edition

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-f, 5-b, 6-e

questions.text: Which of the following personality subtype is more prone to develop “folia-a-deux”?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dependent 

Dependent and weak members of family are more likely to share the delusions of strong members of family.

questions.text: Match the emergency clinical condition, with the most appropriate treatment to be used for the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1-f, 2-b, 3-e, 4-a

questions.text: A patient presented to us with feeling low, hopeless about future, negative emotion, lack of interest, decreased sleep. He reports having similar episode 5 months/5 years back from which he completely recovered. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RDD means more than 2 episodes of depression, at least 2 months apart.

questions.text: A 28 year old mother was diagnosed with mild depression, she has a 3 month old child. Which among the following therapy should be prescribed ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cognitive behavioural therapy

Mild depression, lactating women, psychotherapy alone is the first line of treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of atypical depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Obsessional symptoms

Atypical Depression:

It is characterized by depressed mood, but with reactive affect. Vegetative signs are reversed with hypersomnia, hyperphagia, reversed diurnal mood variation, leaden paralysis, and hypersensitivity to rejection. Effects of MAO inhibitors are better than other antidepressants.
 
Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition

questions.text: A patient having decreased sleep and decreased appetite for last 6 months, also having death wish and has now developed a new symptom for last 2 weeks in form of voices telling him to die, along with persistence of previous symptoms. Treatment (NEET 20)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The diagnosis is severe depression with psychotic symptoms (mood congruent delusions and suicide provoking auditory hallucinations).
Best treatment is antidepressant and antipsychotic, both.

questions.text:
A patient with a diagnosis of depression was started on Fluoxetine, the treatment was given for 2 weeks. After that the relatives noticed that the patient developed new symptoms like, being excessively cheerful, increased excitement, wearing of colourful clothes and increased talking. Which of the following is true. (NEET 20)

A. Diagnosis is drug induced mania

B. A past history of mania/hypomania is likely to be missed

C. This condition could have been prevented by adding mood stablizers, along with antidepressants

D. Fluoxetine must be continued and antipsychotic to be added for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A, B, C are correct

•  As the symptoms of mania came, only after starting of fluoxetine in this patient 

•  Diagnosis is drug induced mania

•  A past history of mania/hypomania is likely to be missed

•  This condition could have been prevented by adding mood stablizers, along with antidepressants

•  And now in treatment, we need to stop fluoxetine and start antimanic/mood stablizers

choices.text: At least four distinct episodes per year

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about “Rapid cyclers”?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Occurs commonly in men
 
Explanation:

A) Incorrect. Rapid cycling actually occurs more commonly in women, not men. This is the answer to the question as it's the statement that is not true about rapid cyclers.

B) Correct. Rapid cycling is indeed commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism. This association has been observed in clinical studies.

C) Correct. The definition of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder includes having at least four distinct mood episodes per year.

D) Correct. Antidepressants can increase the likelihood of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder, which is why their use is often carefully considered in these patients.

questions.text: A 24 year old male was diagnosed as having mania and was started on Tab Lithium 300 mg bd. What is the best time to get serum Lithium levels done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

After 5 days
 
Lithium:

-1st used by John Cade

-Rapid & complete absorption after oral intake

-Excretion by kidney

-Don’t bind to plasma protein.

TDM (Therapeutic drug monitoring)- is required for lithium as it has narrow therapeutic index 

•Acute mania → 1.0- 1.5 mEq/dL 

•Maintenance treatment → 0.6 – 1.2 mEq/dL 

•Toxicity >1.5 mEq/dL

- Serum Lithium levels are advised after 5 days of starting lithium as it takes 5 days for achieving steady plasma concentration.

choices.text: Nocturnal awakenings and early morning awakening
Increase in total duration of REM sleep

questions.text: Most peculiar alteration in sleep neurophysiology in depression is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Reduced REM Latency

Depression is associated with a premature loss of deep (slow wave) sleep and an increase in nocturnal arousal. 

The latter is reflected by four types of disturbance

(1) an increase in nocturnal awakenings

(2) a reduction in total sleep time

(3) increased phasic rapid eye movement (REM) sleep

(4) increased core body temperature. 

“The combination of increased REM drive and decreased slow wave sleep results in a significant reduction in the first period of non-REM (NREM) sleep, a phenomenon referred to as reduced REM latency”. Reduced REM latency and deficits of slow wave sleep typically persist after recovery of a depressive episode.

questions.text:
SEQUENTIAL ARRANGEMENT (AIIMS NEW PATTERN) 

Arrange the following risk factors of “SUICIDE” in decreasing order of importance…

1. Family history of suicide

2. Previous suicidal attempt

3. Ideas of hopelessness

4. Ideas of worthlessness
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2-3-4-1

A previous history of suicide attempt is most important risk factor of suicide.

Amongst cognitive triad of depression, hopelessness is strongest predictor of suicide

questions.text:
True about “Electroconvulsive therapy”?

A. After ECT, CSF levels of BDNF increase

B. Depression with stupor, ECT is treatment of choice

C. Used in treatment of neuroleptic malignant syndrome

D. For a seizure to be effective in the course of ECT, it should last for at least 25 seconds.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ABCD all are true

After ECT, CSF levels of BDNF increase

Depression with stupor, ECT is treatment of choice

Used in treatment of neuroleptic malignant syndrome

For a seizure to be effective in the course of ECT, it should last for at least 25 seconds.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of not being able to leave her house. For the past 5 years, she has had increasing difficulty traveling far from home. She constantly worries that she will not be able to get help if she “freaks out.” In fact, she has had numerous unprovoked episodes of intense fear, associated with shortness of breath, chest pain, diaphoresis, and dizziness, that lasted for 20 minutes. She is convinced that if she drives too far from home, she will have an attack and not be able to obtain help. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This woman most likely has panic disorder with agoraphobia. She experiences recurrent spontaneous panic attacks and between attacks worries about having further attacks. She avoids driving away from her home for fear of being unable to obtain help in the event of an attack.

questions.text: Which symptom is more likely to be found in a patient with social phobia-related panic attacks than in a patient with a primary panic disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Panic attacks can occur in both social phobia as well as in patients with panic disorder. In patients with social phobia however these panic attacks occur with specific social situations and can be expected to occur there. In panic disorder however, the attacks may occur at any time.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman suffered a traumatic event 1 year ago. Since that time, she has been depressed, irritable, angry, and disconnected emotionally. She has trouble sleeping and concentrating. She has nightmares about the rape, tries not to think about it, and avoids going near the place where it occurred. On mental status examination she shows a depressed mood that is congruent with her affect, which is also restricted. She has violent fantasies toward her attacker but no overt homicidal or suicidal ideation. Which of the following has been shown to be the most efficacious treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CBT

The clinical history is suggestive of the diagnosis of PTSD (trouble sleeping and concentrating. She has nightmares about the rape, tries not to think about it, and avoids going near the place where it occurred) and CBT is most effective treatment for PTSD

questions.text: A 25 year female was referred to psychiatrist from plastic surgeon. She wants her entire face changed, repeated visits to plastic surgeons for face deformity, she repeatedly checks her face in mirror. She would constantly examine herself on utensils and spoons complaining about spots and blemishes that are not present.  She wouldn’t change her mind even after family members constantly advising her. Which is best preferred treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Clinical history suggestive of BDD, body dysmorphic disorder, which is a part of OCD and related disorders, and the first line treatment is SSRI (for all neurotic disorders).

questions.text: A girl with a history of loss of consciousness episodes only in front of family members and only in day time. Patient can recall the events at the time of episode, when she regains conscious after 5-10 min, no tongue bite, no history of fecal or urinary incontinence. EEG and MRI brain were normal. Select the true statement regarding her treatment:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Clinical history is suggestive of conversion/pseudoseizure, where the first line of treatment is behavioural therapy.

questions.text: 45 yr old female has feeling of nervousness/feeling tensed, having stomach upset with heartburn/dyspepsia and diarrhea since many years. She also tells her family members are also tensed and nervous. Which additional symptom can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Symptoms mentioned in Q here like nervousness/tensed etc are anxiety symptoms, present for many years, suggestive of GAD.(Generalized anxiety disorder)

GAD also has tingling numbness.

All other options here are psychotic symptoms.

choices.text: Acute psychiatric illness with crisis and uncontrollable patient
Patient with severe chronic psychiatric illness and fragility with dysfunctional ego with good frustration tolerance
Well motivated person for psychotherapy who is not frustrated
Patient with cognitive deficit and physical symptoms

questions.text: Supportive psychotherapy, is not useful in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Well motivated person for psychotherapy who is not frustrated

Explanation:

A) Acute psychiatric illness with crisis and uncontrollable patient: Supportive psychotherapy can be useful in crisis situations to provide stabilization and emotional support.

B) Patient with severe chronic psychiatric illness and fragility with dysfunctional ego with good frustration tolerance: Supportive psychotherapy can be beneficial for chronic patients to maintain functioning and provide ongoing support.

C) Well motivated person for psychotherapy who is not frustrated: This type of patient would likely benefit more from insight-oriented or more intensive forms of psychotherapy rather than supportive psychotherapy. Supportive psychotherapy is typically used for patients who are not able to engage in more intensive therapeutic work.

D) Patient with cognitive deficit and physical symptoms: Supportive psychotherapy can be useful for patients with cognitive deficits or physical symptoms, providing practical support and coping strategies.

Supportive psychotherapy is most useful for patients who need help maintaining or improving their current level of functioning, rather than those seeking deep personal insight or significant behavioral changes.

questions.text: WHO program mh-GAP doesn’t include which of the following disorder in priority list:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

OCD
 
Explanation:

B) OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) is not included in the WHO mhGAP priority list. This is the correct answer.

A) Mental health disorders of childhood are included in the WHO mhGAP priority list.

C) Depression is a key priority in the WHO mhGAP program.

D) Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders are included in the WHO mhGAP priority list.

The WHO mhGAP (Mental Health Gap Action Programme) focuses on scaling up services for mental, neurological, and substance use disorders, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. It prioritizes conditions that cause a high burden of disease and have effective interventions available. It has seven priority conditions:

1. Depression


2. Psychosis

3. Epilepsy

4. Child and Adolescent Mental Health

5. Dementia

6. Substance use


7. Self-harm/suicide

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with multiple, changing physical symptoms over 3 years. Medical evaluations are negative, and she frequently changes doctors. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Somatization Disorder

Explanation:

C) Somatization Disorder: Somatization Disorder, now referred to as Somatic Symptom Disorder in DSM-5, involves multiple, recurrent, and changing physical symptoms over a long period of time that cannot be fully explained by medical conditions. Patients often undergo numerous medical evaluations and frequently switch doctors, as they feel their concerns are not being adequately addressed.

A) Conversion Disorder: Conversion Disorder involves neurological symptoms (e.g., paralysis, blindness) that cannot be explained by medical 
evaluation and are often associated with psychological stress. However, it typically involves a single symptom or a few symptoms rather than multiple, changing physical complaints.

B) Hypochondriasis: Hypochondriasis, now known as Illness Anxiety Disorder, involves an excessive preoccupation with having a serious illness based on misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. The key feature is the anxiety about having a serious illness rather than multiple somatic complaints.

D) Factitious Disorder: Factitious Disorder involves intentional production or feigning of physical or psychological symptoms for the purpose of assuming the sick role, not to obtain external rewards like in malingering. This is different from the involuntary symptoms seen in Somatization Disorder.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of depressed mood, anxiety, and insomnia following the loss of her job. What is the most appropriate diagnosis and initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Adjustment disorder; provide supportive psychotherapy

Explanation:

C) Adjustment disorder; provide supportive psychotherapy: The patient is presenting with depressive symptoms, anxiety, and insomnia following a significant life stressor (loss of her job). The symptoms have been present for 3 months, which aligns with the diagnosis of Adjustment Disorder. Adjustment Disorder occurs in response to a stressful event and is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that are disproportionate to the stressor. The first-line treatment for Adjustment Disorder is supportive psychotherapy, which helps the patient cope with the stressor.

A) Major depressive disorder; start sertraline: While the patient has symptoms of depression, the context and duration suggest Adjustment Disorder rather than Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). MDD requires at least 2 weeks of depressed mood or anhedonia, along with other symptoms, but without a clear external stressor. Sertraline, an SSRI, is a treatment for MDD but not typically the first-line treatment for Adjustment Disorder.

B) Generalized anxiety disorder; start escitalopram: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) involves excessive, uncontrollable worry about multiple events or activities, lasting at least 6 months. The patient's symptoms are linked to a specific stressor (job loss), making Adjustment Disorder more likely than GAD. Escitalopram is used for GAD but is not indicated for Adjustment Disorder.

D) Adjustment disorder; start sertraline: While SSRIs like sertraline can sometimes be used in more severe cases of Adjustment Disorder, the initial management typically involves supportive psychotherapy rather than medication. Medication might be considered if the symptoms are particularly severe or persistent, but it is not the first-line approach.

questions.text: An elderly cancer patient developed symptoms of DELIRIUM, post anaesthesia. What is the initial management/drug to be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Haloperidol

• DOC Delirium (any etiology) : Haloperidol

• DOC Delirium Tremens : IV lorazepam

questions.text: Dementia secondary to which of the following is not reversible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Stroke

Reversible causes constitute only 15% of initial diagnoses of dementia. It is more commonly seen in younger patients.

questions.text: Korsakoff’s syndrome is characterised by all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Impaired procedural memory
 
•  Korsakoff’s syndrome:

•  Cause: Thiamine deficiency

Clinical features:
-  Personality changes including lack of initiative, diminished spontaneity, and lack of interest or concern (Apathy)
-  Confabulation
-  Executive function deficits
-  Passivity

Treatment: Thiamine administration

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a dementing disorder dies in a car accident. During the previous five years, his personality had dramatically changed and he has caused much embarrassment to his family due to his intrusive and inappropriate behavior. Pathological examination of his brain shows fronto-temporal atrophy, gliosis of the frontal lobes’ white matter, characteristic intracellular inclusions, and swollen neurons. Amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are absent. Choose the correct diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pick’s disease accounts for 2.5% of cases of dementia. Clinically it is distinguishable from Alzheimer’s disease due to the prominence and early onset of personality changes, disinhibition or apathy, socially inappropriate behavior, mood changes (elation or depression), and psychotic symptoms. Language is affected early in the disease but the memory loss, apraxia, and agnosia characteristic of Alzheimer’s disease are not prominent until the late stages of the disorder. Temporofrontal atrophy, demyelination and gliosis of the frontal lobes, Pick bodies (intracellular inclusions), and Pick cells (swollen neurons) are the characteristic pathological findings.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A : 3 , B : 1 , C : 4 , D : 2

choices.text: Admit and administer chlordiazepoxide with thiamine
Admit and administer lorazepam with thiamine

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was brought to ER, with complains of talking to self, irritability and irrelevant talks since morning. On further evaluation, there is daily use of alcohol since 6 years, with last drink being 4 days back. Investigations revealed abnormal liver function tests. What is the treatment for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Admit and administer lorazepam with thiamine.

The above scenario is suggestive of Delirium Tremens, which is a complicated state of alcohol withdrawal.
Treatment of Delirium Tremens is Intravenous Lorazepam with thiamine.

questions.text: On physical examination, you notice that a person with a history of substance use, now has pilo-erection, dilated pupils, rhinorrhea, and he is yawning frequently. Withdrawal from which of the following substances can cause this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Opiate
 
These features are suggestive of opiate withdrawal.
 
Opiate withdrawal:

Appears in 4 to 12 hours of last opiate use and subsides within a week.

Clinical features:

(•)Muscle aches and cramps

(•) Insomnia

(•) Diarrhea

(•) Rhinorrhea

(•) Lacrimation

(•) Dilated pupils

(•) Yawning

(•) Piloerection [cold turkey]

questions.text: Mr X has been diagnosed with alcohol dependence. He has been started on disulfiram following a planned detoxification. You educate him about the effects and side effects of the medication. Unfortunately, Mr X decided to start drinking again after taking disulfiram for 1 month. How long should he wait after stopping disulfiram before he can be sure of having no unpleasant side effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1-2 weeks
 
Disulfiram:

It acts by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme, resulting in marked increase in blood acetaldehyde concentration if alcohol is consumed.
Accumulation of acetaldehyde results in unpleasant reactions, called as disulfiram-ethanol reaction.

It is characterised by:
- Nausea and vomiting
- Headache
- Hypertension
- Flushing
- Sweating
- Dyspnoea
- Tachycardia
- Chest pain
- Blurred vision
- Vertigo

•  Occurs immediately after ingestion of alcohol and can last for 30 min to 2 hours.

•  Disulfiram should not be administered until the person has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours.

•  This reaction can occur as long as 1-2 weeks after the last dose of disulfiram.

questions.text: Amotivational syndrome has been described with the use of which of the following substance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cannabis
 
•  Amotivational syndrome:

•  It is a cannabis related syndrome.

•  It is associated with long term heavy use of cannabis.

•  It is characterised by a person’s unwillingness to persist in a task.

•  Loss of ambition and impaired school/ occupational performance.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs caries the highest probability of becoming dependent when you have tried it at least once?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tobacco

(Ref : Stephen stahl textbook 4th edn, pg 546)

•  Tobacco (32%)

•  Heroin (23%)

•  Cocaine (17%)

•  Alcohol (15%)

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl’s family brings her to treatment against her wishes. The family reports she has a very short temper, argues with them and teachers at school daily, often refuses requests at both settings, and usually blames her teachers or her parents for the behaviors she is showing. She denies being depressed , anxious or any psychotic symptoms. With this information, what might be the best diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Oppositional defiant disorder 

Oppositional defiant disorder is a persistent pattern (e.g., 6 months or more) of markedly defiant, disobedient, provocative or spiteful behaviour that occurs more frequently than is typically observed in individuals of comparable age and developmental level and that is not restricted to interaction with siblings. 

Oppositional defiant disorder may be manifest in prevailing, persistent angry or irritable mood, often accompanied by severe temper outbursts or in headstrong, argumentative and defiant behaviour. 

The behavior pattern is of sufficient severity to result in significant impairment in personal, family, social, educational, occupational or other important areas of functioning 
 
Conduct-dissocial disorder 

Conduct-dissocial disorder is characterized by a repetitive and persistent pattern of behaviour in which the basic rights of others or major age-appropriate societal norms, rules, or laws are violated such as aggression towards people or animals; destruction of property; deceitfulness or theft; and serious violations of rules. 

The behaviour pattern is of sufficient severity to result in significant impairment in personal, family, social, educational, occupational or other important areas of functioning. 

To be diagnosed, the behaviour pattern must be enduring over a significant period of time (e.g., 12 months or more). Isolated dissocial or criminal acts are thus not in themselves grounds for the diagnosis

questions.text: An adolescent whose chronological age was 18y, mental age was corresponding to 12y, ; according to binet formula for I.Q. calculation, he should be (as per DSM grading)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dull normal intelligence

There is a catch here. You all know how to calculate I.Q.

But answer is not 66.6 I.Q. (Mild)

Pg 178 kaplan states : (Because it is impossible to measure age-associated changes in intellectual power after the age of 15 with available intelligence tests, the highest divisor in the IQ formula is 15.)

So, for this case

I.Q. is 12/15 * 100 = 80.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl has been referred to a psychiatrist by her teacher because she displays inattention, distractibility, and poor concentration and because her poor academic performance resulted in falling grades. Her parents describe a difficulty in following directions, disorganization, and forgetfulness. She does not have any symptoms of depression, psychosis, or developmental problems. Select the true about treatment of this case:

A. Atomoxetine has a shorter half-life, as compared to methylphenidate

B. Atomoxetine appears to have less of a potential for abuse than methylphenidate.

C. Atomoxetine’s effects begin working immediately to reduce symptoms of ADHD.

D. Atomoxetine can be taken on an empty stomach.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A only 2

Atomoxetine appears to have a lower potential for abuse than Methylphenidate. Initial use can produce a feeling of sleepiness and grogginess, and the drug does not appear to exhibit its effects for up to 3 weeks. It is not recommended to take atomoxetine on an empty stomach, as side effects of the drug include nausea and vomiting. One of the advantages of this drug is that it affords 24-hour control of ADHD symptoms (ie, it has a longer half-life than mehylphenidate)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to a pediatrician with a year-long history of uncontrollable blinking, which has worsened over the past several weeks. The blinking is worse at some times than at others, and the boy is teased at school because of it. The child also clears his throat repeatedly, although nothing physically wrong can be found. He is doing well at school although he sometimes has trouble completing his homework. The patient has a paternal history of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The first line of treatment for this condition is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Diagnosis is Tourette’s syndrome. The first-line of treatment should be an alpha-adrenergic medication such as clonidine or guanfacine. If ineffective the atypical antipsychotics would be the next class of medications to try.

questions.text: A 2.5 year-old child is brought to a pediatrician for his yearly physical examination. His history reveals various behavioral issues, including poor interaction with peers and family, delayed language development, repetitive movements, and difficulty accepting change. The child stiffens physically when touched, does not respond to the examiner, and does not make eye contact. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: 26-year-old man is referred to a psychiatrist as part of the workup for a sex change operation. He has a strong, persistent desire to be female and has dressed as a woman since age 16. His sexual experiences have been exclusively with men. The results of his mental status examination are normal. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Transexualism

Both dual role transvestism and transsexualism, are included in gender dysphoria (person has dissatisfaction with allotted sex and wants to be identified as another sex person)

But sex change operation is being asked by transsexualism, hence the answer

Transvestic fetischism or fetischistic transvestism is a paraphilia.

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the lumbosacral spine
An erection on awakening in the morning

questions.text: A 55-year-old man complains of inability to achieve an erection. He has been worried about his health recently and takes antihypertensive medication. Which of the following would most likely differentiate between an organic and psychiatric condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

An erection on awakening is good evidence of a nonorganic etiology. Because the imaging of the lumbosacral spine may or may not indicate the capacity for erection, these options are not as predictive.

questions.text: A young child wakes up in the middle of the night screaming, frightened, and running to his parents room in this state. He is consolable and recalls a frightening dream in the morning at breakfast. In which stage of sleep did this nightmare likely occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Nightmare disorder is a parasomnia usually associated with the REM stage of sleep. Night terrors usually occur during non-REM sleep.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common symptom of narcolepsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Day time sleep attacks

TETRAD OF NACOLEPSY:

Day time sleep attacks (sudden REM sleep) (Most common symptom)

Cataplexy (Pathognomonic) : loss of tone on emotional events

Hypnagogic (while going to sleep) and hypnapompic (while waking up) hallucinations

Sleep paralysis

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is referred to your office for psychotherapy. She is preoccupied with thoughts of her husband leaving her and being left alone with nobody to take care of her. She feels sad and hopeless when alone, lacks self-confidence, and has great difficulty making decisions. You believe she suffers from a personality disorder. In which cluster does the patient’s most likely diagnosis belong?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

She feels sad and hopeless when alone, lacks self-confidence, and has great difficulty making decisions is suggestive of a diagnosis of dependent personality disorder

Cluster C can also be remembered as the “sad” cluster. It includes dependent, avoidant, and obsessive-compulsive personality disorders. The clusters can be remembered by the words “mad” (cluster A—characterized by odd or eccentric behavior), “bad” (cluster B— characterized by dramatic or emotional behavior), and “sad” (cluster C—characterized by anxious or fearful behavior).

questions.text: A 30 year old male, he is calm and charming in front of psychiatrist, behaves good with family members, but when he is out. He bunks classes, breaks traffic rules, often gets into fights with friends, involved in police interrogation also. What is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Antisocial personality

Breaking rules, indulging in fight with friends, involved in legal cases against etc are suggestive of antisocial.

questions.text: A 20 year-old woman is referred by her gynecologist for the treatment of a possible eating disorder. The gynecologist informs you that the patient presented with a chief complaint of amenorrhea that had been present for 4 months. In addition, the patient has BMI 17.4 kg/m2. Upon evaluation, the patient describes a repeated pattern of bingeing on large meals followed by forced vomiting. She also uses laxatives every night before she goes to bed “to prevent constipation.” The patient reports that she had been running 3 miles every day, but in the last few weeks she has become too tired to run. The most accurate diagnosis for this patient is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Low BMI

Binge

Compensation

Suggestive of

Anorexia

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman has been binging on large quantities of food, above and beyond what most people would eat under similar circumstances. She is embarrassed about the binging and worries that it will make her obese. She then engages in purging behavior, as often as three or four times a week. This behavior accelerates when she is under stress, and the patient feels she has no control over it. The results of her physical examination are normal, and she is of normal weight. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities would most likely be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laboratory abnormalities found in individuals with bulimia nervosa demonstrate hypochloremic-hypokalemic alkalosis resulting from repetitive emesis. Hyperamylasemia and hypomagnesemia are also not uncommonly seen in such patients. Various electrolyte imbalances can occur as a result of frequent laxative abuse. Thyroid abnormalities are not common in individuals with bulimia nervosa.

questions.text: Match the following Sexual perversions with their descriptions:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1-A, 2-C, 3-D, 4-B
 
Explanation:

Eonism refers to cross-dressing for sexual gratification.

Algolagnia is described as sadomasochism, which aligns with the definition of pleasure from inflicting or suffering pain.

Frotteurism is the act of rubbing against a non-consenting person for sexual gratification.

Necrophilia is a sexual attraction to or sexual acts involving corpses.

questions.text: The column 2 of polysomnography set in the given image corresponds to which stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

REM stage
 
Explanation:
 
Awake stage: Brain is fast, eye movement present, muscle movement present

REM sleep: Brain is fast, muscle movement absent (REM has muscle paralysis), eye movements are present (EOG positive)
NREM sleep: Brain is slow, EMG (muscle activity) is positive
 
EMG is flat and EOG is positive, which would indicate REM sleep.

questions.text: Fixation of “Obsessive compulsive disorder” is at which stage of psychosexual development :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anal

questions.text: Most mature defense mechanism
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sublimation

Mature defense mechanisms:

1. Supression (conscious forgetting)

2. Anticipation (all good to happen)

3. Humor (Making fun of all conflicts)

4. Asceticism (rejecting societal comforts)

5. Sublimation (most mature)

6. Altruism (self surrender)

questions.text: The behavioral treatment for enuresis primarily involves the use of an enuresis alarm, alternatively known as a “bell and pad.” this is based on principle of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Classical conditioning

Classic conditioning with the bell (or buzzer) and pad (alarm) apparatus is generally the most effective treatment for enuresis, with dryness resulting in more than 50 percent of cases.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is deeply envious of his younger but much more successful brother. Although it is difficult for him to admit, he believes the younger brother was their parents’ favorite as well. He tells his friends that his younger brother is envious of his good looks and successes with women, even though there is some evidence that this is not so. Defense mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Projection

Projection is the perception of and reaction to unacceptable inner impulses and their derivatives as though they were outside the self.

Attributing one’s own thoughts & feelings  to another.

e.g. An angry man might  accuse others of being hostile and antagonistic.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressant agents is most likely to cause extreme sedation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Trazodone

Solution:

Trazodone:

It is a weak inhibitor of serotonin reuptake and strong antagonist at 5-HT2A and 5-HT2C receptors.

The adverse effects of trazadone are partially mediated by α1-adrenergic receptor antagonism.

The major side effects are:

- Sedation-Therefore used in patients who have depression with insomnia

- Priapism

- Postural hypotension

questions.text: Anti manic response of valproate is associated with a serum levels of valproate as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

50-150 micrograms/ml

(From Kaplan pg 1050, 11th edition , new question)

questions.text: A 31 year old male, with mood disorder, on 30 mg of Haloperidol and 1000 mg of lithium, is brought to the hospital emergency room with history of acute onset of fever, excessive sweating, confusion, rigidity of limbs and decreased communication for a day. Examination reveals tachycardia and labile blood pressure and investigations reveal increased CPK enzyme levels and leucocytosis. He is likely to have developed:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome 

Presence of fever, raised CPK, autonomic instability (labile blood pressure) and rigidity after use of high dose haloperidol (30mg), suggests NMS.

Catch: Patient also has features of lithium toxicity here, confusion, leucocytosis.
But NMS is a better answer.

choices.text: Behavioural and psychological symptoms in dementia
To control aggression in a patient of delirium
To control flashbacks and nightmares in PTSD
To control acute excitement in maniac patient

questions.text: Risperidone is used in psychiatry, in all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

To control flashbacks and nightmares in PTSD patient

Risperidone is used in

Schizophrenia

-  Dementia

-  Delirium

-  Mania

-  Bipolar

-  OCD

-  Agression

questions.text: Which of the following is a dose-dependent side-effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Agranulocytosis can occur at any given dose of clozapine. It is not a dose-dependent effect. The risk of agranulocytosis is higher in the first year of clozapine therapy and gradually reduces over the course of treatment. 

Similarly, neuroleptic malignant syndrome is an idiosyncratic reaction which cannot be predicted in an individual patient. The most important clinical implication to remember is the fact that if a patient has an idiosyncratic side-effect, then this can reoccur at even small doses if rechallenged. Stopping the drug rather than lowering its dose is the appropriate management strategy in such cases. 

Naltrexone produces hepatocellular damage in proportion to the dose administered, especially in patients with pre-existing liver damage.

questions.text: A 48 year old man is prescribed on sodium valproate for prophylaxis against bipolar mania. He develops a confusional state. Liver function tests were within normal limits. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with above presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hyperammonaemia

Side effects of valproate: 

Common:- 

Nausea, Weight gain, Tremors, Alopecia 

Uncommon:- 

Vomiting, Diarrhea, Persistent elevation of hepatic enzymes

Rare:
Fatal hepatotoxicity
Agranulocytosis
Hyperammonemia 
Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition

questions.text: All of the following are included under medical complications seen in anorexia nervosa except? (**)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Low cortisol

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A : 4 , B : 1 , C : 2 , D : 3

Correct match

questions.text: Most common personality disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anankastic personality disorder is most common personality disorder overall

questions.text: Which of the following is matched incorrectly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Emotional lability : Histrionic Personality

Emotional unstability : Borderline Personality
Emotional coldness : Schizoid Personality
Emotional Blunting : Schizophrenia

choices.text: Individuals can engage in a variety of complex behaviors while unconscious
Once awake, the sleepwalker will usually appear normal
Sleepwalker may interact with the environment inappropriately, which sometimes results in injury

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about somnambulism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

“Sleepwalking in its classic form, as the name implies, is a condition in which an individual arises from bed and ambulates without fully awakening. It is sometimes called somnambulism, and individuals can engage in a variety of complex behaviors while unconscious. Sleepwalking usually occurs during slow wave sleep. The sleepwalker often can successfully interact with the environment (e.g., avoiding tripping over objects).

However, the sleepwalker may interact with the environment inappropriately, which sometimes results in injury (e.g., stepping out of an upstairs window or walking into the roadway). There are cases in which sleepwalkers have committed acts of violence. 

An individual who is sleepwalking is difficult to awaken. Once awake, the sleepwalker will usually appear confused. It is best to gently attempt to lead sleepwalkers back to bed rather than to attempt to awaken them by grabbing, shaking, or shouting. In their confused state, sleepwalkers may think they are being attacked and may react violently to defend themselves

choices.text: Loss of function of neuropeptide OREXIN
Paralysis with sleep awake junction hallucinations

questions.text: 30 year old gentleman has excessive sleep at work attributed to sleep discomfort at night. He also has recent history of falling while partying with friends. Other features that can be seen associated with this condition are all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Catalepsy

Diagnosis of this case is narcolepsy

Cataplexy – loss of tone- seen in narcolepsy

Catalepsy – increased tone-seen in catatonia

questions.text: A physician would like to prescribe an antidepressant to treat her 24-year-old male patient who has bulimia. Which of the following agents should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bupropion

Bupropion is contraindicated in eating disorder patients who also purge because it can lower the seizure threshold. The only antidepressant which is FDA approved for patients with bulimia nervosa is fluoxetine.

questions.text: Which of the following personality disorder, was previously also known as “ambulatory schizophrenia”?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Borderline PD

Ref: Kaplan

“Patients with borderline personality disorder stand on the border between neurosis and psychosis, and they are characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behavior, object relations, and self-image. The disorder has also been called ambulatory schizophrenia, as-if personality, pseudoneurotic schizophrenia , and psychotic character disorder .ICD-10 uses the term emotionally unstable personality disorder.”

choices.text: To raise the threshold of penile excitability

questions.text: Sensate focus technique is used in sexual disorders for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

During those exercises, called sensate focus exercises, the couple is given much reinforcement to lessen anxiety. They are urged to use fantasies to distract them from obsessive concerns about performance, which is termed spectatoring.

In cases of premature ejaculation, an exercise known as the squeeze technique is used to raise the threshold of penile excitability. In that exercise, the man or the woman stimulates the erect penis until the earliest sensations of impending orgasm and ejaculation are felt. Penile stimulation is then stopped abruptly, and the coronal ridge of the penis is squeezed forcibly for several seconds. The technique is repeated several times.

questions.text: Basis of Reliability of information of patient provided by informants depend on all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The reliability of the information provided by the informants should be assessed on the following parameters: (Niraj Ahuja) 

1. Relationship with patient, 

2. Intellectual and observational ability, 

3. Familiarity with the patient and length of stay with the patient 

4. Degree of concern regarding the patient.”

choices.text: Telling days of week in reverse order

questions.text: All of the following tests are used to test “Attention and concentration” except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Similarity test

Similarity test is used to assess abstract functioning.

choices.text: Greater likelihood that this behavior caused the initial psychotic episode
Higher probability of the patient developing paranoid-type schizophrenia

questions.text: Families of individuals with schizophrenia who exhibit overt hostility and excessive control have which of the following effects on the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increased relapse rate  

Families of individuals with schizophrenia who display overt hostility, criticism, and excessive control exhibit what is known as high expressed emotion (EE). High EE environments significantly increase the risk of relapse in patients with schizophrenia, even if they are receiving appropriate treatment.  

- A) Increased relapse rate:  
Correct. High EE (characterized by criticism, hostility, and emotional over-involvement) is a well-established factor contributing to higher relapse rates in schizophrenia. Patients in high EE households are more likely to experience exacerbations of symptoms, despite medication adherence.  

- B) Decreased treatment adherence:  
While a stressful family environment may contribute to nonadherence, high EE is primarily linked to relapse, even among patients who continue treatment. Nonadherence is often influenced by factors like medication side effects, lack of insight, or cognitive deficits.  

- C) Greater likelihood that this behavior caused the initial psychotic episode:  
High EE does not cause schizophrenia. Schizophrenia is a neurodevelopmental disorder influenced by genetic and environmental factors, but high EE primarily impacts relapse risk, not disease onset.  

- D) Higher probability of the patient developing paranoid-type schizophrenia:  
There is no strong evidence linking high EE specifically to paranoid-type schizophrenia. Instead, high EE is a general risk factor for worsening symptoms and relapse, regardless of the schizophrenia subtype.

questions.text: A psychiatrist notices that his patients with schizophrenia who smoke cigarettes require higher doses of antipsychotics. This interaction most likely occurs due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CYP1A2 induction  

Cigarette smoking induces cytochrome P450 1A2 (CYP1A2), which leads to increased metabolism of certain antipsychotic medications, particularly clozapine and olanzapine. As a result, smokers often require higher doses of these drugs to achieve the same therapeutic effect.  

- A) CYP1A2 induction:  
Correct. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in cigarette smoke (not nicotine) induce CYP1A2 activity, leading to faster clearance of clozapine, olanzapine, and other drugs metabolized by CYP1A2. Stopping smoking can cause drug levels to rise, increasing the risk of toxicity.  

- B) Dopamine upregulation:  
While nicotine affects dopamine release, it does not directly explain the need for higher antipsychotic doses. Dopamine upregulation is more relevant to nicotine addiction and withdrawal rather than drug metabolism.  

- C) Nicotinic receptor blockade:  
Nicotine activates nicotinic receptors rather than blocking them. Nicotinic receptor modulation has been linked to cognitive improvements in schizophrenia but does not directly alter antipsychotic metabolism.  

- D) Serotonin modulation:  
While nicotine affects serotonin pathways, serotonin modulation is not the primary mechanism behind increased antipsychotic clearance.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia improves on antipsychotics but develops metabolic syndrome. Which intervention would be most appropriate while maintaining therapeutic efficacy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Add metformin  

Metabolic syndrome, characterized by weight gain, hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia, and hypertension, is a common side effect of second-generation antipsychotics (SGAs), particularly clozapine and olanzapine.  

- A) Switch to a typical antipsychotic & B) Switch to a first-generation antipsychotic (FGA):  

- FGAs have a lower risk of metabolic syndrome than some SGAs but higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) and tardive dyskinesia.  

- They may not be as effective for negative symptoms of schizophrenia, making a switch less desirable if the patient is stable.  

- C) Add metformin:  
Correct. Metformin has been shown to be effective in reducing weight gain and improving insulin sensitivity in patients with antipsychotic-induced metabolic syndrome. It allows the patient to continue the current effective antipsychotic while addressing metabolic complications.   

- D) Decrease current dose:  
Reducing the dose may help, but it risks subtherapeutic treatment and relapse. Additionally, some metabolic effects persist even at lower doses.

questions.text: True about Maslow’s hierarchy of needs
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Physiological, Safety, Belonging, Esteem, Self-actualization

Maslow’s hierarchy of needs states that individuals’ main needs are satisfied in the following sequence: physiological, safety, love and belongingness, esteem, and self-actualization.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is seeing a psychiatrist for treatment of her major depressive disorder. After 4 weeks on fluoxetine at 40 mg/day, her psychiatrist decides to try augmentation. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lithium  

In patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) who show partial response to an SSRI (e.g., fluoxetine 40 mg/day for 4 weeks), the next step is augmentation therapy rather than switching to another SSRI. Lithium augmentation has strong evidence for enhancing antidepressant effects, particularly in treatment-resistant depression.  

- A) Lithium  
Correct. Lithium is a first-line augmentation strategy for MDD when an SSRI provides partial improvement. It is particularly beneficial for suicidal patients and those with a suspected bipolar spectrum disorder.  

- B) Sertraline  
Incorrect. Sertraline is another SSRI, and switching between SSRIs is typically done only if there is no response at all. Since the patient has some response, augmentation (with lithium or atypical antipsychotics) is preferred.  

- C) An MAO inhibitor  
Incorrect. Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) (e.g., phenelzine, tranylcypromine) are reserved for treatment-resistant depression when multiple first-line agents fail. They require a 2-week washout due to the risk of serotonin syndrome with fluoxetine.  

- D) Clonazepam  
Incorrect. Clonazepam is a benzodiazepine, which may help anxiety symptoms but does not enhance antidepressant effects or address treatment resistance. It is also not a long-term treatment for MDD due to dependency risks.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with schizophrenia is being treated for cirrhotic liver. Unfortunately, he develops a relapse of psychotic symptoms and needs a change in his antipsychotic prescription. The safest option with regard to his hepatic status is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Amongst antipsychotics, amisulpiride and paliperidone have renal clearance and hence are safe to use in patients with liver disease

questions.text: All of the following seen in serotonin syndrome except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypothermia

questions.text: All of the following side effects are seen more with carbamazepine over oxcarbazepine, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hyponatremia is more seen with oxcarbazepine as compared to carbamazepine, rest of side effects here are more seen with carbamazepine

choices.text: Not an anti craving (decreasing reward response to alcohol) agent

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about DISULFIRAM?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Disulfiram inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase

It causes accumulation of acetaldehyde

It is started at a daily dosage of 250 mg

It is a deterrent agent (aversive therapy) and not an anti-craving

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A : 2 , B : 3 , C : 4 , D : 1

Correct match should be

questions.text: Which of the following terms is used for “experience of seeing oneself and knowing that it is oneself.”
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Autoscopy or phantom mirror-image (Ref : Fish psychopathology)

Autoscopy, also called phantom mirror-image, is the experience of seeing oneself and knowing that it is oneself. It is not just a visual hallucination because kinaestethic and somatic sensation must also be present to give the subject the impression that the hallucination is oneself.

questions.text: Phantom limb is a type of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The phantom limb is the most common organic somatic hallucination of psychiatric origin. In this case the patient feels that they have a limb from which in fact they are not receiving any sensations either because it has been amputated or because the sensory pathways from it have been destroyed. 

In most phantom limbs the phenomenon is produced by peripheral and central disorders. Phantom limb occurs in about 95% of all amputations 
after the age of 6 years.

questions.text: Term "Demence precoce" was coined by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Benedict morel
Remember, “dementia praecox is emil kraeplein”
“Demence precoce is Benedict morel”

choices.text: Preoccupation with the presence of a major life threatening medical illness

questions.text: Which of the following is not included as a type of “monosymptomatic hypochondriacal psychosis”?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Delusional disorder with somatic delusions has been called monosymptomatic hypochondriacal psychosis. 

The three main types are: 

1. delusions of infestation (including parasitosis) 

2. delusions of dysmorphophobia, such as of misshapenness, personal ugliness, or exaggerated size of body parts 

3. delusions of foul body odors or halitosis (sometimes referred to as olfactory reference syndrome)
